data.title: Casa del Emilio (Indio Fernandez), Mexico City, Mexico – Museum Review
data.meta_description: Find Casa del Emilio (Indio Fernandez), Mexico City, Mexico ratings, photos, prices, expert advice, traveler reviews and tips, and more information from Condé Nast Traveler.
data.text:
What’s this place all about?

The former home of Mexican actor/screenwriter/director Emilio Fernandez, now a museum, is set on a tree-lined street in Coyoacán.

How's the permanent collection?

As you walk around the house, you'll see Fernandez's possessions still as he placed them; visitors get a unique window into the filmmaker's life during the 1940s and '50s. The home itself, made of volcanic stone, is a well-preserved example of Mexican architecture during that era.

And the exhibits?

I highly recommend visiting during Day of the Dead. When I went, the whole house was decorated with marigolds (the Day of the Dead flower), altars, and skeletons of famous actors and friends of Fernandez.

What did you make of the crowd?

This museum attracts many locals and some Mexican visitors. There were few foreign tourists during my visit, since the museum still flies relatively under the radar.

On the practical tip, how were facilities?

Since the house is quite old, there is no elevator and the staircases are quite narrow; those with accessibility limitations might want to skip.

Any guided tours worth trying?

Guided tours offer deeper insights into the life of Emilio Fernandez and the Golden Age of Mexican cinema in the 1940s and 1950s.

Gift shop: obligatory, inspiring—or skip it?

There is no gift shop, but when I visited, there was a small market outside selling handicrafts from around Mexico.

Is the café worth a stop, or should we just plan on going elsewhere?

There is also no café. A few market stalls sold food on the day I visited. You can find several nice cafés within walking distance from the museum.
